    Recent Advances in β2-Agonists for Treatment of Chronic Respiratory Diseases and Heart Failure

    • Gang Xing
      Gang Xing
      Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmaceutical Engineering, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Shenyang 110016, China
      Key Laboratory of Structure-Based Drug Design and Discovery of Ministry of Education, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Shenyang 110016, China

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    β2-Adrenoceptor (β2-AR) agonists are widely used as bronchodilators. The emerge of ultralong acting β2-agonists is an important breakthrough in pulmonary medicine. In this review, we will provide mechanistic insights into the application of β2-agonists in asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and heart failure (HF). Recent studies in β-AR signal transduction have revealed opposing functions of the β1-AR and the β2-AR on cardiomyocyte survival. Thus, β2-agonists and β-blockers in combination may represent a novel strategy for HF management. Allosteric modulation and biased agonism at the β2-AR also provide a theoretical basis for developing drugs with novel mechanisms of action and pharmacological profiles. Overlap of COPD and HF presents a substantial clinical challenge but also a unique opportunity for evaluation of the cardiovascular safety of β2-agonists. Further basic and clinical research along these lines can help us develop better drugs and innovative strategies for the management of these difficult-to-treat diseases.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Vital body functions such as respiration and circulation are under the control of the autonomic nervous system made up of neurons, neurotransmitters, and receptors on target tissues. The cardiovascular system and the pulmonary system are responsive to sympathetic stimulations due to the presence of adrenoceptors (ARs) on effector cells. The myocardium and airway smooth muscles (ASMs) mainly express β-adrenoceptors (βARs), while vascular smooth muscles express both αARs and βARs. These receptors belong to the G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) superfamily and are traditional drug targets. βAR agonists and antagonists (blockers) are essential medicines widely used in the treatment of cardiovascular and pulmonary disorders.(1)
    Heart failure (HF) is a condition in which the heart’s ability to pump blood is weakened such that the cardiac output cannot match with the metabolic demand of the body. HF may occur as an acute condition or chronic illness. Preexisting cardiovascular conditions such as ischemic heart disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus and advance in age are the most important risk factors for chronic HF. On the basis of the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), chronic HF is classified into three types: that with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF, LVEF < 40%), with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF, LVEF ≥ 50%), and with midrange ejection fraction (HFmrEF, 40% ≤ LVEF ≤ 49%).(2) According to the current statistics from the American Heart Association, about 6.2 million Americans over the age of 20 suffered from HF in 2013–2016, and an increment of 46% in prevalence will occur from 2012 to 2030, bringing the total number of affected people to >8 million.(3) According to the data from the National Center for Health Statistics of the United States, 1 in 8 deaths in death certificates have mentioned HF among multiple causes.(4) In addition, the total cost of HF in the United States is estimated to increase from $30.7 billion in 2012 to $69.8 billion in 2030.(3) The mortality and hospitalization rates of patients with HF have reduced recently due to the application of guideline-recommended therapies, particularly the use of β-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, cardiac resynchronization therapy, implantable cardioverter-defibrillators, and other treatments in patients with HFrEF.(2,3,5) However, there are no specific treatment strategies to decrease mortality and hospitalization rates of patients with HFpEF due to an incomplete understanding of the pathophysiology and therapeutic targets and inadequacy in disease definition and classification.(2,5,6) The 5-year mortality rate of HF remains high at 42.3%.(3)
    Asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are the most common chronic respiratory diseases.(7) According to the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) definition, asthma is a heterogeneous disease of the airway characterized by typical symptoms such as wheeze, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough.(8) The Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study group has found that about 272 million people had asthma in 2017 globally.(7) Asthma has a global prevalence ranging from <5% to ≥20% in adolescents and an estimate of 8.6% in adults.(9) COPD is characterized by persistent respiratory symptoms and airflow limitation that is due to airway and/or alveolar abnormalities usually caused by significant exposure to noxious particles or gases.(10) The most common symptoms of COPD are shortness of breath and a cough that produces sputum. COPD affected the lives of more than 299 million people in 2017(7) and is the fourth leading cause of death in the world.(11) Chronic respiratory diseases were the second leading causes of global disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs) in 2017.(12) Airflow obstruction, which is readily reversible spontaneously or with treatment in asthma but persistent and progressive in COPD, is a common underlying condition responsible for the cause of clinical symptoms in both diseases.(8,10,13,14) In addition, inflammation of the airways contributes to the pathogenesis of both diseases.(8,10,14) Thus, the use of bronchodilators (β2-agonists, muscarinic antagonists, and theophylline) to decrease airway resistance and anti-inflammatory drugs (corticosteroids, leukotriene (LT) receptor antagonist, and phosphodiesterase (PDE) 4 inhibitors) to treat chronic airway inflammation has become standard approaches in the treatment of asthma and COPD.(8,10,15) Nevertheless, up to 17% of asthma patients have difficult-to-treat asthma.(8) In addition, comorbidities are common among people with COPD and are associated with poorer prognosis.(10) HF is a frequent and important comorbidity of COPD.(10) HF can worsen COPD and vice versa.(10) Patients with severe asthma or severe exacerbation in COPD have a low responsiveness to inhaled reliever medications.(8,10)
    In the present review, we will highlight different aspects encompassing the pharmacology, mechanism of action, clinical usage, and research and development of β2-agonists and to a smaller extent β-blockers with respect to asthma, COPD, and HF, with a special emphasis on the use of β2-agonists and β-blockers in combination as a novel therapeutic strategy for HF and the application of the concept of functional selectivity in drug discovery.

    2. Mechanisms of Action

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. βAR Signaling in Cardiac Physiology and HF

    The β-adrenergic system plays a pivotal role in the regulation of myocardial function. Catecholamines released in response to sympathetic stimulation activate cardiac βARs to produce the classical positive chronotropic (change in heart rate), inotropic (change in contractile force), and lusitropic (change in relaxation rate) responses. Stimulation of the βARs activates the canonical stimulatory G proteins (Gs)-adenylyl cyclase (AC)-cAMP-protein kinase A (PKA) signaling cascade. The PKA-dependent enhancement effect of β-adrenergic stimulation on cardiac excitation–contraction coupling has been well-documented.(16) In sinoatrial nodal cells and cardiomyocytes, the phosphorylation of PKA substrates, such as phospholamban (PLB), ryanodine receptor (RyR) 2, L-type Ca2+ channel (LCC), T-type Ca2+ channel, potassium channel IKs and funny channel enhances intracellular calcium ([Ca2+]i) dynamics, while the phosphorylation of cardiac troponin I (cTnI) and cardiac myosin-binding protein C (cMBP-C) reduces myofilament Ca2+ sensitivity. Consequently, [Ca2+]i transient and contractility increase in cardiomyocytes and automaticity increases in sinoatrial nodal cells.
    The human heart expresses all of the three subtypes of the βAR with the β1AR being dominant. These βAR subtypes play an important role in the regulation of myocardial contractility, but they serve distinct functional roles in the heart as they display different signal transduction properties. For instance, while the β1AR couples only to Gs proteins, the β2AR couples to both Gs and inhibitory G proteins (Gi) (Figure 1A).(17) Thus, stimulation of the β2AR usually produces a maximal contractile response that is less than what could be attainable with β1-adrenergic stimulation. It is partly because the concomitant activated Gi proteins counteract the effect of the activated Gs proteins on cAMP synthesis. The distinct functional roles of the β1AR and the β2AR are also attributed to the different spatial distribution of the two receptor species on the surface of the myocardial membrane. β1ARs have an even distribution on the sarcolemma (plasma membrane of myocytes).(20) In contrast, β2ARs are localized mainly within signal complexes in caveolin 3-enriched subdomains of the sarcolemma including caveolae and T-tubules.(21−23) Within these membrane compartments are a myriad of regulatory proteins for β-adrenergic signal transduction, including LCC,(24) Gi,(25,26) and PDEs, which restrict the diffusion of cAMP.(27,28) Because of the compartmentation of the β2AR-mediated cAMP signaling, unlike the global effect of the cardiac β1AR-stimulated cAMP/PKA signaling as described above, the β2AR-stimulated increase in cAMP is uncoupled from the phosphorylation of many cytosolic proteins including PLB, cTnI, and cMBP-C though β2-adrenergic stimulation remains capable of increasing the L-type Ca2+ current (ICa,L).(29) As a result, the β2AR-stimulated cAMP signaling is uncoupled to [Ca2+]i dynamics and contractility in single ventricular myocytes(30) as well as in vivo hearts.(31)
    The distinct signaling property of the β2AR makes it a key regulator to guard against excessive catecholamine stimulation of the heart. First, in a process known as heterologous desensitization, PKA-dependent phosphorylation of the β2AR, which can be the result of either β1- or β2-adrenergic stimulation, promotes the switching of G protein coupling preference of the β2AR from Gs to Gi.(32) Second, β2-adrenergic stimulation-induced “offside” compartmentation, which involves GPCR kinase (GRK) 2-dependent recruitment of β-arrestin 1 and PDE4 to the C-terminus of the nearby β1AR, restricts β1AR signaling into submembrane microdomains in cardiomyocytes such that a normal β-adrenergic response beyond ICa,L increment is not elicited.(33)
    β-Adrenergic dysfunction is an important pathophysiological mechanism of HF. A leading hallmark of this molecular change is a decreased responsiveness of the heart to catecholamines (Figure 1B), which leads to exercise intolerance of the affected person.(34) In HF, serum catecholamine levels are constantly high due to compensatory activation of the sympathetic nervous system.(35) Prolonged stimulation of cardiac βARs leads to receptor desensitization and downregulation, which are critically involved in myocardial dysfunction in HF.
    The mechanisms of desensitization involve phosphorylation of the activated βAR and recruitment of the adaptor protein β-arrestin. In the classical model of homologous desensitization, GRK2-dependent phosphorylation of the cytoplasmic domain of the β2AR facilitates recruitment of β-arrestin which terminates β2AR-Gs signaling and triggers receptor internalization.(36) Other mechanisms distinct for the β2AR include phosphorylation-dependent enhancement of the β2AR-Gi coupling(32,37) and the formation of a β2AR/β-arrestin/PDE4D complex in the vicinity of membrane-associated PKA.(38−40) Homologous desensitization of the β1AR appears to be less robust than that of the β2AR.(41) It involves PKA or GRK phosphorylation of the β1AR,(42) and the two types of phosphorylation result in receptor endocytosis through different pathways.(43) The link of most of the above mechanisms to the pathogenesis of HF is not strong. In fact, some of them may even act as protective adaptations to guard against excessive catecholamine stimulation.
    On the other hand, evidence suggests that downregulation of the cardiac β1AR is a major cause of reduced responsiveness of the failing heart to catecholamine stimulation.(34) With a reduction of the expression of the β1AR by 50% and the unchanged expression levels of the β2AR during disease progression, the ratio of β1AR:β2AR on membrane surface drops from 4:1 in the normal condition to 3:2 in human HF.(44)
    In addition, the failing human heart also has increased expression of GRK2 and Gi,(45,46) which may be key mediators of the functional decline in HF. A recent study has suggested that phosphorylation of the β2AR by GRK2 promotes a β2AR-Gi biased signaling in a pressure overload-induced HF model.(37) This exaggerated β2AR-Gi signaling uncouples Gs proteins from both β1ARs and β2ARs and links GRK2 upregulation to HF. The cross-inhibition of the β1AR-Gs signaling by the β2AR-Gi signaling is HF-specific and not found under normal conditions, as evidenced by the resumption of the β-adrenergic responsiveness of myocardial contractile responses in whole animals and cells with experimental Gi or GRK2 inhibition.(37,47−52) The mechanism of the cross-inhibition is far from clear but may be a function of increased expression of GRK2, Gi, and Na+/Ca2+-exchanger,(45,46,52) redistribution of β2ARs from T-tubules to the cell surface in HF,(23,53) and β2AR-mediated “offside” compartmentalization of β1AR-signaling.(33)
    The β1AR and the β2AR play opposing roles in cardiomyocyte survival and death (Figure 2).(54) Persistent β1-adrenergic stimulation is cardiotoxic and residual signal transduction capacity of the β1AR is sufficient to inflict harm on the failing heart.(55) Cellular and whole animal studies have revealed that long-term stimulation of the β1AR activates Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII), a key mediator of arrhythmias,(56,57) apoptosis,(58,59) and maladaptive cardiac remodeling.(60,61) Furthermore, the important role of the CaMKII-δ9 splice variant in human HF has recently been substantiated by the fact that the δ9 isoform is the most abundant CaMKII-δ isoform expressed in the human heart and is involved in ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme E2T (UBE2T)-dependent DNA repair.(62) Its upregulation in various cellular injury models in neonatal rat cardiomyocytes and a pressure overload-induced cardiomyopathy model in mice promoted accumulation of DNA damage and genome instability. Myocardium from patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy had lower abundance of UBE2T compared with healthy controls, and human embryonic stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes overexpressed with CaMKII-δ9 also had reduced expression of UBE2T.(62)
    Multiple signal transduction pathways have been proposed to relay persistent β1-adrenergic stimulation to CaMKII activation. On the basis of data from cellular and genetic knockout mouse models, Mangmool and colleagues(63) have proposed a PKA-independent mechanism involving specific recruitment of β-arrestins to the C-terminus of the activated β1AR and interaction of cAMP with exchange protein directly activated by cAMP (EPAC), a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for the small GTPase Ras-related protein 1 (Rap1). In this mechanism, β-arrestin acts as a scaffold for the formation of a cardiotoxic β-arrestin-CaMKII-EPAC1 signal complex with the β1AR. However, recent evidence from a PKA inhibitor peptide transgenic mouse model suggests that EPAC can also mediate cardioprotective signals with β1-adrenergic stimulation(64) or the use of some antidiabetic drugs in HF.(65) Another mechanism to increase CaMKII activity in β1AR-stimulated cardiomyocytes is by raising [Ca2+]i, which stabilizes the Ca2+/calmodulin complexes.(66) An increased [Ca2+]i could be due to increased ICa,L(58,67,68) or increases in sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ via PKA-mediated phosphorylation of PLB.(64) The resultant activation of CaMKII with increasing incidence of SR Ca2+ leak can lead to cardiomyocyte death in HF as evidenced by studies on CaMKII-δ isoform transgenic and knockout mice.(69,70) In addition, β1-adrenergic stimulation-induced cardiomyocyte death in vitro and in vivo has been shown to depend on crosstalk between the β1AR and the receptor for advanced glycation end-products (RAGE) pathway converging to a common downstream mediator CaMKII.(71)
    The deleterious effect of excessive β1-adrenergic stimulation in HF is well-established.(55) The use of β-blockers to block β1AR is now standard of care for patients suffering from HFrEF.(2,5) Although β-blockers suppress contractility when treatment is initiated, their long-term use in HF can protect the human heart and restore its responsiveness to catecholamine stimulation.(72−74) Recent experimental progress has also given hope on the translation of CaMKII inhibition into a treatment strategy for HF and related myocardial anomalies.(75−79)
    In contrary to the cardiotoxic nature of the β1AR, the β2AR is a cardioprotective receptor.(54) Cardiac overexpression of the β2AR at 30-fold over the basal level has been shown to prevent maladaptive cardiac remodeling and improved cardiac function in a Gαq-overexpressing mouse model of HF.(80) On the other hand, deficiency of the β2AR increased isoproterenol-induced apoptosis of ventricular myocytes in mice(81) and animal death in a doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy model.(82) In consistent with these observations, HF patients carrying a loss-of-function Ile164 mutation in the ADRB2 (β2AR) gene exhibited a higher mortality rate relative to patients without this mutation.(83,84) Cardioprotection associated with the β2AR is often attributed to the ability of the receptor to elicit an antiapoptotic Gi-Gβγ-phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)-Akt signaling.(85) The importance of the β2AR-Gi signaling in cardioprotection is further substantiated in our recent observational study involving hospitalized patients with chronic HF.(86) We found that patients carrying the minor β2AR-Gly16 allele had increased risks of cardiovascular death in an allele dose-dependent manner and the increase in risks was associated with the inability of the β2AR-Gly16 variant to elicit a Gi signaling. However, it should be noted that while the β2AR-Gi signaling is cardioprotective and upregulated in HF to counteract the cardiotoxic β1AR-CaMKII signaling, the resultant salutary effect on cardiomyocyte survival comes at the expense of a compromised contractile reserve (or exercise capacity) as detailed above.(37,87)
    As opposed to the β1AR-Gs signaling, the β2AR-Gs signaling is neutral or cardioprotective rather than cardiotoxic. In fact, the beneficial effect of the Gs-biased β2-agonist fenoterol has been repeatedly demonstrated in animal models of HF.(88−93) It has been suggested that the activation of CaMKII is β1AR-specific because the engagement of β-arrestin with the C-terminus of β1AR results in a unique conformational shift of β-arrestin that allows for scaffolding of EPAC and CaMKII to form a stable complex, leading to the subsequent cAMP/EPAC-mediated activation of CaMKII. But the engagement with the C-terminus of β2AR results in a different conformation of β-arrestin that does not favor this complex formation.(63) This explains why sustained β2-adrenergic stimulation does not induce cardiomyocyte death while sustained stimulation of the β1AR does. The cardioprotective mechanism of the β2AR-Gs signaling is unclear but may be the result of engaging crosstalk with the tyrosine kinase receptor signaling leading to Akt phosphorylation(94,95) or provision of the needed contractile support to the failing heart.(93)
    The functional significance of the cardiac β3AR has also been revealed in recent years. As opposed to the β1AR and the β2AR, the β3AR couples to Gi proteins and has been found to inhibit norepinephrine-induced cAMP synthesis in rat cardiomyocytes(96) and to produce a negative inotropic effect in human myocardial tissues.(97) It is upregulated in HF in human(98) as well as pacing-induced HF in dogs(99) and has been suggested to participate in the functional degradation of the failing heart.(98,99) However, mice with transgenic cardiac-specific expression of the human β3AR are protected from cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis in response to isoproterenol or angiotensin II stimulation.(100) Therefore, there is no specific conclusion regarding the role of the β3AR in HF. β3AR agonists and antagonists are under investigation for HF and other conditions.(101−104)

    2.2. Pathophysiology of Asthma and COPD, and Mechanisms of Drug Action

    Asthma is a disease with a complicated and heterogeneous pathophysiology characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness, airway remodeling, and inflammation,(105) which collectively result in the dysfunction of ASMs. Airway inflammation is a leading cause of airway hyperresponsiveness and ASM hyperplasia.(106,107) Airway hyperresponsiveness is a symptom characterized as bronchospasm that could be triggered by allergens, air pollutants, and oxidative stress.(108) Airway remodeling that increases the ASM mass contributes to the risk of exacerbation.(106)
    Recent studies on the pathophysiology of asthma have substantially changed our understanding of the disease. It is now recognized that asthma is a group of disorders encompassing a collection of different disease subtypes (or phenotypes) with different underlying pathophysiological mechanisms that might be identified by corresponding biomarkers (or endotypes).(105) Earlier attempts in asthma phenotyping have resulted in different groupings based on clinical features with little regard for the underlying mechanisms.(109) Characterization of the endotypes, on the other hand, may provide important framework for research and development of personalized asthma treatment.(110) Research on asthma immunology in the past two decades has made tremendous progress in revealing the inflammatory processes involving various immune cells and cytokines that leads to asthma. On the basis of the current understanding of its pathophysiology and molecular features, asthma is categorized into two main endotypes, namely T2-high and T2-low, with T2 referring to T-helper type 2 (Th2)-driven inflammation or simply type 2 inflammation.(111) Reviews on this topic are available.(109,110,112)
    The majority of asthma cases, including early onset allergic asthma and late-onset eosinophilic asthma, fits into the T2-high asthma endotype that is mediated by type 2 cytokines, classically interleukins (IL)-4, IL-5, and IL-13. The characteristic features of the T2-immune response include atopy, allergy, type I hypersensitivity reactions, and eosinophilic inflammation.(109) In a classical and simplified scheme of the interactions between inflammatory cells and mediators in T2-high asthma, pathogen/allergen-exposed dendritic cells promote naı̈ve CD4+ T lymphocytes to differentiate into Th2 cells.(113) The activated Th2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines are also produced by group 2 innate lymphoid cells which express no antigen receptors for T or B lymphocytes.(112,114) IL-4 generates more Th2 cells from naı̈ve T cells via an autocrine loop. It also causes class switching of B lymphocytes to produce IgE class antibodies which binds to FcεRI receptors on the surface of tissue mast cells and blood basophils.(112) IL-5 is essential for the maturation, activation, and chemoattraction of eosinophils from the systemic circulation into inflamed tissues.(114) IgE, mast cells, and eosinophils constitute an important defense line against parasitic infection,(115,116) but mast cells and eosinophils are also key effector cells in asthma. Allergen-sensitized mast cells degranulate to release multiple bronchoconstrictor factors, resulting in airway hyperresponsiveness. Eosinophils produces chemical mediators which promote persistent inflammation and airway remodeling. A well-recognized function of IL-13 is to drive the differentiation of airway epithelial cells into active goblet cells that produce mucins resulting in sputum formation. In addition, IL-13 also induces airway hyperresponsiveness and contributes to airway remodeling.(112,117)
    T2-low asthma is loosely defined as asthma in the absence of prominent T2-pathway signatures.(118) More recent studies suggest that T2-low asthma may actually comprise different endotypes, which is currently an active area of research.(110,112) T2-low asthma is typically associated with later age of onset, milder symptoms, obesity, smoking, and low responsiveness to corticosteroids as compared with T2-high asthma.(109,118) The pathophysiology underlying T2-low asthma is less well-understood. In many cases of T2-low asthma, the levels of neutrophils rather than eosinophils are high. Neutrophilic asthma is usually associated with high levels of Th1 and Th17 cells.(112) Type 1 immunity (Th1-mediated) and type 3 immunity (Th17-mediated) are believed to play roles in the pathophysiology of T2-low asthma.(118) By secreting IL-17 and IL-22 cytokines, Th17 cells mediate the recruitment and activation of neutrophils to elicit a cell-mediated immune response against extracellular microbes. Also, interferon-γ, the prototypical Th1 cytokine, activates macrophages to promote phagocytosis, oxidative burst, and the eradication of intracellular microbes, but under pathological conditions such as asthma, these mechanisms can induce inflammation and tissue damage.(113,118,119)
    Proliferation of ASM cells (ASMCs) is the pathogenic basis of ASM hyperplasia and airway remodeling. Allergens facilitate the release of proinflammatory cytokines, CXC chemokines, and collapsins (known as semaphorins), and these factors subsequently enhance the proliferation and migration of ASMCs and increase collagen deposition.(119,120) Moreover, ASMCs themselves produce chemokines, cytokines, and growth factors.(120) Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) is one of the most potent factors that could markedly potentiate ASM contraction and remodeling.(121) The mechanism of its action involves enhancement of [Ca2+]i and mitochondrial biogenesis.(122,123) It has been suggested that β2-agonists reverses PDGF-induced ASMC proliferation by modulating [Ca2+]i and mitochondrial fission/fusion.(124) Conversely, other studies have found that mast cells can blunt the ASM relaxant effect of β2-agonists by secreting growth factors (e.g., transforming growth factor (TGF)-β1), which activate tyrosine kinase receptors leading to the phosphorylation of the tyrosine residues on the β2AR.(125)
    COPD is caused by a complex interaction among genes and environment. Smoking is the central environmental factor causing airway inflammation. The level of inflammation determines the severity of COPD.(126) The inflammatory immune response induced by tobacco smokes, bacteria, or viruses causes airway tissue injury and remodeling.(127−129) The resultant thickening of airway walls and/or narrowing of small airways impair ventilation and respiratory function. Activation of immune cells such as monocytes and T lymphocytes as well as neutrophilic infiltration and inflammation of the lungs marks the pathological distinction of COPD as compared to asthma.(130) The activated macrophages and T cells release chemokines and factors such as IL-8, CXCL2, and LTB4, which recruit neutrophils to the lungs, and the neutrophils generate enzymes such as myeloperoxidase, neutrophil elastase, and matrix metallopeptidases causing damage to alveoli.(130,131) Consequently, fibrosis (repair of the wound by replacement with connective tissues) leads to irreversibly narrowing of the airways. This process occurs early in COPD.(131) In addition, proliferation of ASMCs also participates in the pathogenesis of COPD by increasing airway hyperresponsiveness and ASM mass.(132) While inflammation is the common pathogenic mechanism for both asthma and COPD, the inflammatory cells and mediators involved are different. Asthma (primarily the T2-high endotype) is described as eosinophilic, while COPD is described as neutrophilic.(133) In addition, mast cells do not seem to play a significant role, while macrophages appear to play a major role in orchestrating the inflammatory response in COPD.(131) The T lymphocytes involved are also different. Th1 and Type 1 cytotoxic T cells (Tc1) are activated in COPD, while Th2 cells are activated in asthma.(133) These differences probably explain the low responsiveness of corticosteroids in COPD. However, specific differences are not fully clear, and severe asthma and COPD often exhibit similar inflammatory profiles where the distinctions among them become blurred.(130)
    Bronchodilators are commonly used for symptomatic treatment of asthma and COPD. Stimulation of the β2AR by β2-agonists or blockade of the M3 receptor by muscarinic antagonists produces bronchodilation via ASM relaxation (Figure 3). Contraction and relaxation of ASMs are governed by the phosphorylation status of regulatory light chain of myosin (rMLC). Phosphorylation of rMLC by the myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) produces contraction, while dephosphorylation of rMLC by the myosin light chain phosphatase (MLCP) brings about relaxation.(134) MLCK is a Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent kinase. Its activity is positively corelated with [Ca2+]i.(135) Stimulation of Gq– coupled receptors such as M3 receptors or histamine H1 receptors in ASMCs activates the phospholipase C and inositol triphosphate (IP3) signaling pathway, triggering a sudden release of stored Ca2+ via IP3 receptors and RyRs on SR membranes and subsequently produces contraction.(136) In contrast, stimulation of the Gs-coupled β2AR activates PKA, increasing the phosphorylation of multiple downstream PKA substrates including IP3 receptors, a number of sarcolemmal Ca2+ channels, and proteins important for the regulation of MLCP activity.(137−139) This leads to reduced [Ca2+]i, [Ca2+]i dynamics, and Ca2+ sensitivity resulting in the relaxation of ASMs.(134) Besides, studies have shown that β2-agonists inhibit PDGF-induced proliferation of ASMCs.(124,140) The mechanism may involve attenuation of [Ca2+]i waves or PKA-dependent inhibition of ASMC migration.(124,141) Other mechanisms of action of β2-agonists include anti-inflammation and inhibition of pro-fibrotic events.(142,143)

    3. β2-Agonists

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. Pharmacological Diversity of β2-Agonists

    β2-Agonists vary in their pharmacological properties which affect their clinical performance. First of all, receptor subtype selectivity determines specificity of an agonist toward its target. According to a study about determination of the relative selectivity of different β-agonists at β1-, β2-, and β3-AR, the nonselective β-agonist isoproterenol (isoprenaline) had a 3.8-fold higher selectivity for the β2AR over the β1AR, while the β2-agonists salbutamol (albuterol) (1) and salmeterol (2) (Table 1) had, respectively, a 21.4-fold and a 3388-fold higher selectivity for the β2AR over the β1AR.(144) This suggests that β2-agonists can cross-activate the β1AR to some extent. In general, a β2-agonist with a high β2/β1-selectivity is desirable, as reduced activation of the β1AR lowers the risk of adverse cardiac effects such as tachycardia. Another important pharmacological characteristic of a β2-agonist is its efficacy, also called intrinsic activity. β2-Agonists may be categorized as full agonists or partial agonists based on the levels of their effects in functional assays. The maximum effect attainable from a full agonist is a full response, while the effect of a partial agonist is submaximal at full receptor occupancy. Clinical studies have shown that full β2-agonists display greater responses but also increased adverse effect profiles as compared with partial β2-agonists.(145−147) In a head-to-head comparison between the full agonist formoterol (3) (Table 1) and the partial agonist salmeterol (2) in a double-blind, crossover, placebo-controlled design, salmeterol (2) showed a flatter dose–response curve on the relief of methacholine-induced bronchoconstriction as compared with formoterol (3), and it caused a significantly lower tremor score and a smaller drop in serum potassium than formoterol (3).(146) Characterization of the β2/β1-selectivity and comparison of the intrinsic activities in bronchodilator and inotropic or chronotropic actions have become a common practice in preclinical testing of β2-agonists to gain an understanding of their safety margins.(148−150)
    Table 1. Chemical Structures and Pharmacological Properties of Selected β2-Agonists in Use Clinically
    The potential of an agonist to trigger desensitization is also an important consideration. Continuous stimulation of the β2AR leads to homologous desensitization (see also section 2.1). Desensitization results in the loss of an effect after repeated dosing of a drug, also called tolerance or tachyphylaxis. The occurrence of tolerance is particularly relevant for agonist drugs used in the treatment of chronic diseases such as asthma and COPD.(151) Moreover, it has been long known that the effectiveness of β2-agonists in relieving bronchospasm can decrease over time.(151) Because a full β2-agonist could produce a clinically relevant bronchodilator response at a subsaturating concentration and at a lower receptor occupancy relative to a partial β2-agonist, it likely triggers fewer receptors into desensitization.(152) Therefore, the repeated use of a partial β2-agonist may have a higher chance of causing a loss of the bronchoprotective effect compared with that of a full β2-agonist. An early clinical study has shown that salmeterol (2) is a partial agonist while formoterol (3) is a full agonist.(146) Besides, recent biophysical studies have demonstrated that salmeterol (2) is less efficacious in inducing the active conformations of the β2AR for coupling to Gs as compared with a full agonist.(153,154) Interestingly, both salmeterol (2) and formoterol (3) cause similar degrees of β2AR desensitization though via different mechanisms.(155) Formoterol (3) enhances receptor internalization.(155) In contrast, receptor internalization is not a major contributor of salmeterol-induced desensitization.(155,156) Other studies have shown that salmeterol (2) stimulation causes GRK phosphorylation of the β2AR but has a little effect on recruitment of β-arrestins.(156) On the contrary, salmeterol (2) operates a highly amplified PKA/PDE-mediated β2AR desensitization although it has a low efficacy in inducing cAMP accumulation.(157) Newer β2-agonists such as indacaterol (4) and olodaterol (5) (Table 1) appear to induce less β2AR desensitization or tachyphylaxis as compared with the second-generation agents.(148,158) It may be due in part to their full agonist status.(152) In addition, combination with a corticosteroid has been shown to substantially reduce desensitization of the full β2-agonist formoterol (3) in cell assays.(155) This finding correlates with the clinical superiority of the inhaled corticosteroid (ICS)/formoterol (3) combination compared with β2-agonist or ICS alone in the control of asthma (see section 3.3).
    As mentioned above, both receptor phosphorylation and β-arrestin recruitment play roles in receptor desensitization. Molecules involved in GPCR desensitization, including GRKs and β-arrestins, are also major players of functional selectivity, also called biased agonism. Functional selectivity describes a selectivity bias of the agonist-stimulated receptor signaling toward different pathways downstream of a single GPCR.(159) It is now apparent that the β2AR can relay its signal through interacting with different cellular proteins. Some of them are membrane-bound, like receptors of a different family.(160) Others are cytosolic, such as G proteins, GRKs, and β-arrestins. Ligands preferentially directing receptor to mediate its signal via certain pathways at the expense of others, also known as biased ligands, have been described.(161) Moreover, biased ligands that induce a β-arrestin-biased signaling independent of G protein activation have also been described.(162) Carvedilol, a nonselective β-blocker, has been classified as a β-arrestin-biased β2-agonist under this definition.(163) Carvedilol was able to promote phosphorylation of the GRK sites on β2AR, recruitment of β-arrestins, β2AR internalization, and activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) while possessing an inverse efficacy in stimulating cAMP synthesis.(163) Apart from these “extreme” examples of functional selectivity, a bias toward preferential β-arrestin over Gs signaling or vice versa is another possibility.(164) On the basis of the idea that β2AR desensitization contributes to the loss of bronchoprotective effect,(165) it is expected that a β2-agonist with a signaling bias for Gs over β-arrestin, such as salmeterol (2),(154,164) would be preferred over one with a reversed bias due to a lower potential to induce receptor desensitization. Moreover, recent studies have suggested an important role of β-arrestins in signal transduction and as regulators of a multitude of pathophysiological processes including inflammation and apoptosis.(166,167) These concepts may have important implications in the development of bronchodilator β2-agonists.
    Apart from the pharmacological properties mentioned above, the onset of action and the duration of action are obviously important parameters for a β2-agonist as detailed below.

    3.2. Development of β2-Agonists

    β2-Agonists remain the first-line therapeutic agents for both asthma and COPD. Development of inhaled β2-agonists has been enormous over the past decades. The first-generation β2-agonist has a rapid onset of action and a short duration of action. Salbutamol (1), a prototypical short-acting β2-agonist (SABA), was first developed by Sir David Jack at Allen and Hanburys, a subsidiary of Glaxo (now GlaxoSmithKline), in the 1960s.(168) It has a salicyl alcohol headgroup and a tertiary butyl tail in its molecule. It has a fair potency compared with isoproterenol but its selectivity for β2AR over β1AR is significantly higher.(144,168,169) Salbutamol (1) and other SABAs are commonly used to relieve acute bronchoconstriction in asthma and COPD.
    On the basis of the structure of salbutamol (1), Sir David Jack and colleagues set out on a long journey for the development of the first long-acting β2AR agonist (LABA), currently regarded as the second-generation agent. A long alkoxyaryl group was added to the tail of salbutamol (1) to increase lipophilicity, resulting in a compound with a duration of action of more than 12 h. Salmeterol (2) was finally launched in 1990.(169) Recent crystallographic data show that the long aryloxyalkyl tail of salmeterol (2) binds to the exosite sites of the β2AR by van der Waals and hydrophobic interactions.(154) The position of the oxygen atom is important for fitting the long tail to the exosite sites by forming a hydrogen bond with the main chain amide group of the Phe193 residue.(154,170,171) Compared to salbutamol (1), salmeterol (2) has an increased selectivity for β2AR over β1AR,(144,169) which contributes to a low cardiac toxicity. The second-generation β2AR agonists, such as salmeterol (2) and formoterol (3), are typically used in combination with an ICS for long-term treatment of asthma, or as monotherapy or in combination with a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) and/or an ICS to treat COPD.(172) Formoterol (3) with two chiral centers in its molecules was first synthesized in its racemic form in the 1970s.(173) The stereoisomers of formoterol (3) displayed different biological activities. The (R,R)-isomer was the most potent one among them in producing tracheobronchial muscle relaxation in isolated guinea pig trachea.(174) Formoterol (3) has an N-(5-(2-amino-1-hydroxyethyl)-2-hydroxyphenyl)formamide headgroup and an α-methyl-β-(4-methoxyphenyl)propane-amino tail group in its molecule. The 4-methoxyphenyl group contributes to an increased lipophilicity as compared with salbutamol (1). Formoterol (3) was found to have a rapid onset of action similar to salbutamol (1) and a 12 h duration of action.(172,175,176) In 2001, formoterol fumarate was commercialized through a collaborative effort by Novartis and Schering-Plough (now Merck and Co.) for the treatment of COPD patients requiring long-term regular bronchodilator therapy. The drug is administered twice daily.
    Recently, a new class of third-generation agents known as ultra-LABAs with a duration of action of more than 24 h have emerged.(177) These drugs including indacaterol (4),(175) olodaterol (5),(178,179) and vilanterol (6)(180) were marketed for the treatment of COPD.(177) Indacaterol (4) was the first ultra-LABA developed by Novartis as a once-daily inhaled bronchodilator.(175) It was approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 2011 and by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) in 2009. The indacaterol (4) molecule is composed of an 8-hydroxyquinolin-2(1H)-one headgroup and a symmetrically substituted indan moiety at its tail. In addition, the 5,6-diethylindan moiety, in particular, has an important contribution to form a long duration of action extending over 24 h and a rapid onset of action.(175) Ingo Konetzki et al. have synthesized a series of 6-hydroxy-4H-benzo[1,4]oxazin-3-ones as potent agonists of the human β2AR with a high β2/β1-selectivity.(178) These compounds were assessed for application as inhaled once-daily long-acting bronchodilators. Olodaterol (5), also known as BI1744CL,(179) consists of a 6-hydroxy-4H-benzo[1,4]oxazin-3-one headgroup and a 2-(4-methoxyphenyl)ethan-1-amino tail with two germinal methyl groups at the α-carbon next to the amine (Table 1). The methoxy substituent at the terminal phenyl group plays a vital role in improving the duration of action of olodaterol (5) due to increased lipophilicity.(179) Structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies have revealed that the phenolic hydroxyl group at the meta-position of the 4H-benzo[1,4]oxazin-3-one head contributes to an increased β2/β1-selectivity relative to their ortho-hydroxyl counterparts.(178,179) An ortho-hydroxyl derivative of the 4H-benzo[1,4]oxazin-3-one-containing compound named BI167107 (7) (Figure 4) is one of the LABAs discovered by Boehringer Ingelheim. BI167107 (7) binds strongly with the β2AR and has been used to support crystallization of the active state β2AR complexes and can be employed as a tool for the crystallization of other β-ARs.(181,182) Procopiou et al. have identified an ultra-LABA, vilanterol (6), from analogues of salmeterol (2).(180) Incorporation of an oxygen atom at the homobenzylic position of the terminal phenyl ring of salmeterol (2) with ortho-substitution of two chlorine atoms in it gives vilanterol (6). In docking simulations, the middle oxygen atom of vilanterol (6) formed a hydrogen bond with Asn318 whereby the benzylic ether oxygen formed two hydrogen bonds with Ser120 and Asn322, respectively. Vilanterol (6) had a high potency and a high β2/β1-selectivity similar to salmeterol (2) and exhibited a more rapid onset of action and very little washout on electrically stimulated isolated superfused guinea pig trachea. It was thus expected to have a long duration of action in vivo. Its metabolism by human liver microsomes was faster compared to salmeterol (2) and it had a very low oral bioavailability in rats. This pharmacokinetic profile is favorable for an inhaled bronchodilator.(180)
    A number of β2AR agonists are currently under clinical development. Bedoradrine (8), a new tetrahydronaphthalene derivative, is a novel, highly selective β2-agonists intended for the intravenous treatment of status asthmaticus.(183−185) Clinical data show that in patients with acute exacerbation of asthma, bedoradrine (8) (1200 μg, one time, with monitoring hourly for 3 h) in the background of standard therapy did not significantly affect percentages of forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1) at 3 h compared to placebo but was associated with significant improvement in dyspnea scores. The adverse effect profile of bedoradrine (8) was similar to that of other β2-agonists. Bedoradrine (8) may be used to manage symptoms in patients with acute exacerbation of asthma uncontrolled by inhaled β2-agonists.(183) Abediterol (9), a dual β2-agonists and muscarinic antagonist with an 8-hydroxyquinolin-2(1H)-one headgroup developed for asthma and COPD, exhibited an agonistic effect on the β2AR with an Emax of 91 ± 5% compared with isoproterenol in a cellular model overexpressing the human β2AR.(186) The EC50 value of abediterol (9) was 1.9 nM in isolated human bronchi. Its onset of action was similar to that of formoterol (3), and its duration of action was similar to that of indacaterol (4) in guinea pigs. In dogs, it produced more sustained bronchoprotective effect than salmeterol (2) and indacaterol (4) at doses without effects on heart rate.(186) It had a long half-life of 36 h compared with 51 h for indacaterol (4), 47 h for olodaterol (5), and 18 h for vilanterol (6) in guinea pigs.(150) Abediterol (9) at 2.5, 5, and 10 μg once daily for 7 days significantly improved pulmonary function versus placebo in patients with stable and persistent asthma and exhibited a safety and tolerability profile compared with placebo.(187) In patients with COPD, single-dose abediterol (9) at 2.5, 5, and 10 μg significantly improved trough FEV1 compared with indacaterol (4), 150 μg. Incidence of adverse events was similar between the groups.(188) Trantinterol (10) with a nonclassical 2-amino-2-phenylethanol core structure (Figure 4) is a potential drug candidate for asthma.(189) In a randomized, multicenter clinical study conducted in China, the treatment effects of trantinterol hydrochloride and procaterol hydrochloride in 223 eligible participants were compared.(190) After a run-in period of 3 days, patients in the treatment group and the control group were given 50 μg of the tablet drugs twice daily for 10 days. The results showed that improvement in FEV1 was significant and similar in both groups. There were also no significant differences between the groups in other parameters including days with rescue medication use, symptom score, lung function, vital signs, and adverse effects. The results demonstrate that the use of trantinterol hydrochloride tablets for asthma control is safe and effective.(190) Biological studies have shown that trantinterol (10) is a highly selective β2-agonist with strong tracheal relaxant activities in guinea pigs and rabbits.(189) Trantinterol (10) at 0.01 (equivalent to 50 μg or maximum recommended dose in human), 0.1, and 1 ng/mL did not cause significant inhibition of cytochrome P450 enzymes in human liver microsomes in vitro, demonstrating a low potential for drug–drug interactions.(191)
    A number of novel β2-agonists have appeared in recent literature, but detailed information about their further development are hardly available. Procopiou et al. have synthesized a series of LABAs incorporating an arylsulfonamide group.(192) Compound 11 was identified as a candidate compound that possesses a high potency and a long duration of action. To search for new LABAs, chemists in Pfizer have designed and synthesized a series of saligenin analogues(193,194) including compounds 11, 12, 13, 14, and 15.(195) Compound 15 was found to have an effective duration of more than 24 h (Figure 5).
    Roger et al. have described a series of catecholamine type compounds with high β2/β1-selectivity.(196) Compounds 16, 17, 18, and 19 (Figure 6) exhibited high potencies, with Kiβ2AR values of 32, 25, 97, and 25–70 nM, respectively. Compounds 17 and 19 displayed excellent β2/β1-selectivity compared to compounds 16 and 18. Liang et al. have discovered a group of β2-agonists from the natural product Rhizoma Curcumae.(197) Compounds 20 and 21 (Figure 6) has agonistic actions on the β2AR, with EC50 values of 23.82 and 5.925 μM, respectively. Compound 22 was found to have no activity. New compounds 23, 24, and 25 were isolated from purslane (Figure 6).(198) Their anti-inflammatory activities were evaluated in RAW 264.7 murine macrophages. All of the tested compounds exhibited potent anti-inflammatory activities, with EC50 values ranging from 17.96 to 497.67 μM. Compounds 25 also showed agonistic effects on the β2AR in CHO-K1/Gα15 cell line, with EC50 values of 87.86 nM. Compound 25 was suggested to be a dual functional agent exhibiting strong β2-agonistic and anti-inflammatory effects.(198) On the basis of the 2-amino-2-phenylethanol scaffold, a series of compounds including trantinterol (10) analogues, compounds 26(199) and 27,(200) have been designed and synthesized (Figure 6). The structure of compound 26 was based on the 8-hydroxyquinolin-2(1H)-one head of indacaterol (4) and the ethanolamine core of trantinterol (10), and compound 27 was designed by bioisosteric replacement of the ortho-phenyl moieties on the 4-aminophenyl head of trantinterol (10). When tested under in vitro or organ bath assays, these compounds exhibited high potency and selectivity toward the β2AR.(199,200)
    Conventional drug discovery at the β2AR have led to the development of ligands that bind almost exclusively to the receptor’s orthosteric site. However, in recent years, functionally active allosteric ligands which bind to sites other than the orthosteric sites have been discovered. It has been demonstrated by FDA approvals and clinical trials that GPCR allosteric modulation is a novel drug discovery strategy and broadens potentially useful small molecular species.(201) For example, Lefkowitz lab reported the first negative allosteric modulator of β2AR compound 28 (Figure 7) in 2017 through screening the DNA-encoded small-molecule libraries.(202,203) It has been found that the para-formamidophenylalanine and the meta-bromobenzyl scaffold play vital roles in the activity of compound 28.(204) A positive allosteric modulator of β2AR compound 29 (Figure 7) was also discovered in 2018.(205) Compound 29 exhibits low micromolar affinity for the β2AR allosteric site and can enhance the affinity of conventional β2AR agonists to bind on the orthosteric site, with the ability to coordinate downstream signal transduction proteins such as G proteins and β-arrestins to mediate downstream signal transduction. The Lefkowitz lab in cooperation with the Kobilka lab at Tsinghua University in China reported the crystal structure of an activate conformation of the β2AR bound with compound-6FA, a carboxylic acid derivative of compound 29.(206) Allosteric ligands usually display greater receptor subtype selectivity than orthosteric ligands because allosteric sites may not face the same evolutionary pressure as do orthosteric sites and thus are more divergent across subtypes within a receptor family.(206) This is exemplified by the fact that just 1 out of 15 amino acid residues constituting the ligand-binding pocket of the human β2AR is different from that of the human β1-AR,(207) whereas the allosteric site for compound-6FA binding lies within the intracellular loop (ICL)2 domain of the β2AR known to have low structural similarity compared with the ICL2 domain of the β1AR.(206,208) Therefore, drugs targeting allosteric sites potentially have fewer adverse effects. Recently, Kobilka lab reported a newly developed allosteric modulator of the β2AR compound 30 (Figure 7) as a negative allosteric modulator for agonists and positive allosteric modulator for inverse agonists.(209) Compound 30 binds to a different site compared with two other allosteric modulators, compounds 28 and 29. The binding site of compound 30 locates on the lipid bilayer facing regions of transmembrane (TM)3 and TM5. Compound 28 binds to a pocket formed by the cytoplasmic ends of TMs 1, 2, 6, and 7.(202,203) Compound 29 binds to the cytoplasmic ends of TMs 3 and 4.(206,209)

    3.3. Inhaled β2-Agonists: Clinical Practice and Development

    Current algorithm in asthma treatment follows a stepwise approach.(8) As-needed SABAs are commonly used as reliever medications in all steps. However, multiple studies have suggested that regular use of SABAs in the absence of anti-inflammatory treatment offers no benefit and could even worsen asthma control.(210−212) Earlier asthma management guidelines still recommend SABA as reliever medication with regular low dose ICS only as an option in step 1 and regular low dose ICS with as-needed SABA in step 2. LABA can be added if symptoms remained uncontrolled in step 2.(213) A fundamental change has been made on the 2019 and subsequent GINA recommendations, emphasizing the need to include an ICS whenever a SABA is used.(214) With regard to the initial treatment in mild asthma, the preferred treatment is as-needed low dose ICS with formoterol (3) in step 1 and regular low dose ICS and as-needed SABA or as-needed low dose ICS with formoterol (3) in step 2.(8) This change is based on strong evidence that as-needed budesonide/formoterol (3) is superior to as-needed SABA alone and noninferior to regular budesonide in the control of mild asthma.(215−217) Similarly, regular LABA is associated with increased risks of exacerbation and hospitalization in asthmatics,(177,218) while regular LABA and ICS in combination (mometasone furoate/formoterol (3),(219) budesonide/formoterol (3),(220) and fluticasone propionate/salmeterol (2)(221)) reduces side effects and the severity of the disease, particularly in patients with moderate or severe asthma. In addition, regular ICS/LABA produces more benefits in moderate-to-severe asthma as compared to ICS alone(222,223) while having no significant effect on cardiovascular risks.(224) Therefore, ICS/LABA is the recommended initial treatment for patients with moderate-to-severe asthma to alleviate symptoms and to reduce the risk for exacerbation.(8,213) Also, meta-analyses have shown that ICS/formoterol (3) used as single maintenance and reliever therapy is more effective than regular ICS with as-needed SABA in treating persistent asthma.(225,226) The 2019 update of the GINA guideline recommends ICS/formoterol (3) as the preferred reliever across all steps of the asthma treatment algorithm.(214)
    LABA either as monotherapy or in combination with ICS and/or LAMA in COPD management has a history of about 30 years. These bronchodilator medications are most commonly given on a regular basis to achieve symptom control.(10) The use of LABAs in COPD is not associated with changes in mortality and adverse effects.(227) An as-needed SABA alone or in combination with a short-acting muscarinic antagonist is recommended as the reliever medication in COPD, but the use of short-acting bronchodilators on a regular basis is not recommended.(10) Recent pharmaceutical research has resulted in the successful development of ultra-LABAs with a duration of action of more than 24 h and a fast action onset.(175,179,180) Ultra-LABAs such as indacaterol (4) and olodaterol (5) improve lung function and symptoms and decrease the risk of exacerbation in COPD compared to LABAs,(228,229) while having no significant effects on survival and risks of adverse events.(230,231) Their use in a once-daily dosing regimen improves the compliance of COPD patients through decreasing the frequency of delivery.(231,232)
    Up to now, ultra-LABAs are only indicated for maintenance treatment in patients with COPD. No specific guidance on their use in asthma has been provided as clinical trials are still ongoing. Published data about indacaterol (4) and olodaterol (5) only provide the evidence that they maintain effective relaxation for over 24 h in asthma, and there is no specific dose and dose frequency for olodaterol (5) or its combination with ICS.(233) Recent studies have shown that the new combination mometasone furoate/indacaterol acetate, also known as QMF149, may be a potential therapeutic option for asthma.(234,235) In addition, the efficacy of fluticasone furoate/vilanterol (6) in asthma has also being evaluated.(236,237) The once-daily dosing regimen associated with the use of these agents is an advantage over the traditional ICS/LABA combination therapy as adherence is enhanced.
    The medical community has a concern over the cardiovascular safety of inhaled β2-agonists.(238) Tachycardia, tremor, and decrease in serum potassium are the most common side effects of extra-pulmonary β2-adrenergic stimulation.(239,240) These side effects are usually mild and appear when inhaled β2-agonist treatment is first initiated. Most of them gradually subside when treatment is prolonged, indicating desensitization of the β2AR.(241−243) Several reports have suggested that β2-agonists may increase the risks of arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death, myocardial infarction, and HF, particularly during initiation of treatment.(241,244−250) Nevertheless, the increased risks are usually related to high dosage or underlying cardiovascular disease rather than the direct effect of the β2-agonists.(145,245−247,249) The overall safety profile of β2-agonists is considered acceptable, but the cardiovascular risks of individual patients should be carefully assessed during clinical decision making.(8,10,251)

    3.4. Application of β2-Agonists with Combination in Coexistent COPD and HF

    COPD and HF often coexist, as they share common risk factors, for instance aging and cigarette smoking. Overlap of COPD and HF occurs in about 30% (with a range from 8% to 52%) of patients suffering from either of the diseases.(252,253) β-Blockers and β2-agonists are the cornerstones of therapies for HF and COPD, respectively. As the actions of these two classes of drugs dramatically oppose each other, their use in patients with COPD-HF overlap has raised a number of concerns.
    LABAs have been suggested to increase the risk of cardiovascular adverse events.(241,254) However, a recent meta-analysis has shown that LABAs are not associated with an overall increased risk of cardiovascular adverse events, and formoterol (3) and olodaterol (5) might even reduce the risks of some cardiovascular adverse events,(251) but LABAs might increase the risk of HF while reducing the incidence of hypertension.(251) The outcomes can be interpreted as the fact that β2-agonists stimulate β2ARs in the cardiovascular system leading to vasodilation, an increase in heart rate, a reduction in serum potassium levels, and an increased risk of arrhythmias.(241) According to the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) report,(10) the overall safety profile of LABAs in patients with cardiovascular complications is considered acceptable. Nevertheless, caution is advised when using SABAs. As conclusive safety data about β2-agonists in patients with COPD and HF are still unavailable, it would be prudent to closely monitor patients when bronchodilator treatment is first initiated.(242)
    The concern about bronchospasm caused by β-blockers is ungrounded, as the benefits of β-blockers in COPD-HF overlap have been clearly demonstrated. Studies have shown that cardioselective β-blockers, especially bisoprolol, produced no bronchospasm and exhibited benefits in reducing mortality and exacerbation in patients with coexistent COPD and HF.(255−258) However, the long-term effects of β-blockers on pulmonary function remain uncertain.(254) According to current guidelines, cardioselective β-blockers beginning at a low dose followed by up-titration to the target or maximum tolerated doses should be applied in HF patients with comorbid COPD.(2,5) In addition, asthma is not an absolute contraindication for cardioselective β-blockers.(2,5) Chronic administration of β-blockers has even been shown to reduce inflammatory changes related to airflow obstruction and airway hyperresponsiveness in mice.(147,259)
    Combination of LABA with LAMA or ICS may reduce adverse effects associated with the use of individual agents.(260,261) A recent retrospective analysis has revealed that patients with coexistent COPD and HF using cardioselective β-blockers had the greatest reduction in mortality risk.(262) ICS/LABA combinations, LAMAs, angiotensin receptor blockers, nonselective β-blockers, and statins were also associated with significant risk reduction, while SABAs, LABAs alone, and ICSs alone had minor effects. Unexpectedly, LABA/LAMA combinations have been found to be associated with a slightly higher cardiovascular risk as compared with LABAs alone and LAMAs alone which showed similar risks.(263) In a more recent cohort study of COPD patients with a history of HF,(264) the use of indacaterol (4)/glycopirronium, an ultra-LABA/LAMA combination, was associated with beneficial cardiovascular outcomes.
    A possible cause of the cardiovascular adverse effects associated with the use of β2-agonists is off-target stimulation of the cardiac β1AR. As cardioselective β-blockers can ameliorate the cardiovascular adverse effects caused by inhaled β2-agonists while not causing bronchospasm, combining a β2-agonist with a selective β1-blocker has a good rationale for use in COPD-HF overlap.(252) Future studies should focus on the analysis of the cardiovascular risks with different drug combinations.

    3.5. β2-Agonists for HF Management: Research and Development

    While the cardioprotective role of the β2AR is well-established (section 2.1), the usefulness of β2-agonists in cardiac conditions such as HF is still a matter of debate.(265) When inhaled SABAs have just become widely available for asthma control, there was an increase in the reported cases of adverse events, sometimes including death, associated with the use of β2-agonists.(247−250,266,267) Most of these adverse events can be attributed to overdosage, tolerance, or misuse such as the underusage of anti-inflammatory medications.(210,268) However, the perception that β2-agonists increase the risks of HF, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death has since been formed among clinicians, while no definitive clinical evidence in favor of or contrary to this assumption has ever been provided.(246,269−273)
    On the other hand, experimental studies have repeatedly shown that β2-agonists alone or in combination with β-blockers produced benefits in various animal models of HF.(88−92,274−277) Xiao and colleagues have shown that a selective β2-agonist fenoterol preferentially stimulated the β2AR to couple to Gs proteins, while most of the other β2-agonists such as salbutamol (1), procaterol, and zinterol stimulated the receptor to induce dual Gs and Gi signalings.(88) The other agonists did not produce a full contractile response in adult rat cardiomyocytes as did fenoterol, a full β2-agonist. But in cardiomyocytes in which the Gi proteins had been inhibited by pertussis toxin (PTX), the contractile responses of these “partial” agonists were augmented to levels similar to a full response. In contrast, the contractile response of fenoterol was insensitive to treatment with PTX. In addition, fenoterol induced a full contractile response in cardiomyocytes isolated from heart failing spontaneously hypertensive rats while responsiveness to stimulation with zinterol was substantially reduced in these cells. These data suggest that fenoterol is a Gs-biased β2-agonist with respect to Gs/Gi signaling and has a potential applicability in HF.(88) A follow-up study in a myocardial infarction-induced rat cardiomyopathy model showed that short-term treatment with fenoterol for 3 months produced a strong cardioprotective effect as compared with metoprolol, a β-blocker, as exemplified in the reduction of cardiomyocyte apoptosis and infarct area expansion, and improvement in left ventricular function, cardiac remodeling, and hemodynamic indices.(89) These protective effects, including improvement in cardiac structure and function and animal survival, gradually waned away when the treatment was continued for 12 months.(91) Interestingly, cotreatment of fenoterol with metoprolol greatly enhanced the cardioprotective effect and a synergistic action of the drugs was clearly evident.(91) A possible interpretation of the results is that continuous treatment with a β2-agonist leads to β2AR desensitization and consequently the loss of protection, which can be effectively prevented by coadministration of a β-blocker. Similar synergistic actions of β2-agonists and β-blockers in improving cardiac structure and function in HF models have also been reported with other β2-agonist/β-blocker combinations such as indacaterol (4)/metoprolol and clenbuterol/metoprolol.(276,277) In addition, a recent randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial has shown that salbutamol (1) improved pulmonary vascular reserve in HFpEF without worsening left heart congestion.(278) Combination of mechanical and pharmacological therapy including the use of clenbuterol and β-blockers has also been successful in reversing severe HF in a few small-scaled clinical studies.(279,280) Therefore, the usefulness of β2-agonists in HF is still an open question and likely be context-dependent. Confounding factors such as disease stages, comorbidities, and accompanying medications are anticipated to greatly affect treatment outcomes and should be taken into consideration during the study design.
    We have employed a medicinal chemistry approach to discover novel β2-agonists with potential applicability in HF and other cardiac conditions. On the basis of the scaffold of fenoterol, compounds containing a 5-(2-amino-1-hydroxyethyl)benzene-1,3-diol structure were designed and synthesized. Biological activities of these compounds were assessed by biophysical and cellular assays including contractility measurement in adult rat cardiomyocytes.(281−285) (R,R)-Fenoterol (31) was found to be the most active stereoisomer of the parent compound fenoterol.(282) SAR analyses revealed that the biological activities of these compounds depend on the presence of an (R) configuration on the first chiral carbon, whereas the stereochemistry of the second chiral center affects both activity and subtype selectivity.(282,283) Fenoterol analogues with a terminal 1-naphthyl and/or a 4-methoxyphenyl moiety on the tail group, i.e., compounds 32 and 33 exhibited comparable affinity and improved subtype selectivity relative to the parent compound either by engaging in hydrogen bond or π–π interactions with the β2AR.(284) The presence of an ethyl group instead of a methyl group on the second chiral carbon, i.e., compound 34 also contributes to improved subtype selectivity (Figure 8).(285)
    Recent studies have implicated the role of the β-arrestin-biased βAR signaling in cardioprotection which may serve as a mechanistic basis for the development of novel HF therapeutics.(286) Noma and colleagues have initially described a cardioprotective β1AR signaling induced by carvedilol which is β-arrestin-dependent but G protein-independent, suggesting a possible new mechanism of the therapeutic action of carvedilol in treating HF.(287) Later, Kim and group members discovered that the β-arrestin-biased β1AR signaling activated by carvedilol has a novel function of regulating micro-RNA (miR) biogenesis.(288) They subsequently showed that the β2AR can also mediates carvedilol-activated β-arrestin-biased signaling, which causes the upregulation of several cardioprotective miRs.(289) Meanwhile, Benovic and group members synthesized allosteric modulator peptides (pepducins) targeting the cytosolic portion of the β2AR, with an aim to produce a β-arrestin-biased signaling on a vacant receptor.(290) One of the pepducins, ICL1–9, has the ability to induce β-arrestin-dependent and Ca2+-independent contractility in adult mouse cardiomyocytes.(290) Tilley and group members subsequently showed that ICL1–9 protects cardiomyocytes both in vitro and in vivo in a β-arrestin- and β2AR-dependent manner.(291)
    Littmann et al. have attempted to discover β-arrestin-biased β2-agonists from some existing β2AR ligands, including fenoterol analogues, but could only find a few compounds with Gs-biased agonism, and no compounds showed a significant selectivity bias toward β-arrestin.(292) We have also synthesized and tested a number of compounds for agonist bias for β-arrestin versus Gs/cAMP signaling using the HTRF cAMP assay and the PathHunter β-arrestin assay in β2AR-expressing cells.(164) In this study, agonist biases of compounds were defined using an “unbiased β2-agonist”, isoproterenol, as a reference. We confirmed that salmeterol (2) is a Gs-biased β2-agonist while fenoterol is unbiased.(292) We also discovered that three new β2-agonists based on the 5-(1-amino-2-hydroxyethyl)-8-hydroxyquinolin-2(1H)-one scaffold,(199) compounds 35–37, preferentially activated a β-arrestin-biased signaling (Figure 9).(164) As a β-arrestin-biased β2-agonist may have an additional cardioprotective potential compared to a unbiased β2-agonist, its usefulness in HF and other cardiac conditions warrants further investigation. In view of their low potencies, these compounds are better to serve as templates for further optimization.

    4. Summary and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Asthma, COPD, and HF are difficult-to-treat diseases. Development of more effective treatment for these diseases is urgently needed. The use of β2-agonists in chronic respiratory diseases for symptomatic relief has a strong scientific basis and has already been widely applied. The development of ultra-LABAs and ICS/β2-agonist combination therapy are examples of important recent advances in pulmonary medicine. In the present review, we have provided deepened insights into the pathophysiology of asthma, COPD, and HF and the mechanisms of action, SARs, clinical uses, and potential applications of β2-agonists, with an aim to benefit development of β2-agonists with high potency, high selectivity, fast action onset, long duration of action, and low potential to induce receptor desensitization for bronchodilator therapy and potential cardiovascular applications. In addition, we have also given a detailed account on basic and translational studies that have provided a mechanistic framework and experimental evidence to support the use of β2-agonists in HF. Evaluation of the safety profiles of β2-agonists in different clinical settings are urgently needed to guide drug usage. In particular, association studies of the cardiovascular risks in COPD and HF overlap with β2-agonist/β-blocker combination therapy should be conducted to provide the needed foundation for further evaluation of the efficacy and safety of this drug combination. Furthermore, the advent of the concept of functional selectivity and allosteric modulation has innovated drug discovery with the discovery of novel pathways, mechanisms, and treatment strategies. Novel drugs from this class may include, for examples, Gs-biased β2-agonist for the treatment of asthma and β-arrestin-biased β2-agonist for the treatment of HF. Future studies should focus on the design of β2-agonists with fewer side effects using innovative approaches such as structure–functional selectivity relationship analysis.

    6. 6
      Bonsu, K. O.; Arunmanakul, P.; Chaiyakunapruk, N. Pharmacological treatments for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction a systemic review and indirect comparison. Heart Failure Rev. 2018, 23, 147– 156,  DOI: 10.1007/s10741-018-9679-y
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Pharmacological treatments for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction-a systematic review and indirect comparison
      Bonsu, Kwadwo Osei; Arunmanakul, Poukwan; Chaiyakunapruk, Nathorn
      Heart Failure Reviews (2018), 23 (2), 147-156CODEN: HFREFC; ISSN:1382-4147. (Springer)
      Pharmacol. interventions for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) have failed to reduce mortality and hospitalization. Evidence for mineralocorticoid antagonists (MRAs), β-adrenoceptor blockers (β-blockers), and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ACEIs/ARBs)-to reduce clin. outcomes in HFpEF remains unclear. We conducted a systematic search of MEDLINE, EMBASE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, and Clin. Trials.gov for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) assessing pharmacol. treatments in HFpEF diagnosed according the recommendations of the European Society of Cardiol. (ESC) 2016 guidelines from inception to August, 2017. The study outcomes were mortality, hospitalization, changes in indexes of cardiac structure and function, biomarkers, and indexes of functional capacity-quality of life (QoL) assessment and 6-min walk distance test (6-MWD). The random-effects models were used to est. pooled relative risks (RRs) for the binary outcomes and standardized mean differences for continuous outcomes, with 95% CI. A network meta-anal. using a random-effects model was employed to est. the comparative efficacy of treatments. We included data from 15 RCTs comprising 5930 patients. There was no significant effect seen with all treatments compared with placebo and comparative efficacy of any two treatments on all outcomes assessed. However, mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone demonstrated a trend towards reducing mortality compared with placebo (RR 0.92; 95% CI 0.79-1.08), sildenafil (0.14; 0.01-2.78), perindopril (0.87; 0.59-1.28), and eplerenone (0.91; 0.25-3.33). Similar trends in treatment effect were obsd. with spironolactone on surrogate outcomes while eplerenone demonstrated a trend of superior effect in redn. of hospitalizations compared with all other drug treatment. No drug treatment demonstrated statistically significant improvement in clin. and surrogate outcomes in HFpEF diagnosed according to the ESC 2016 guideline. Spironolactone and eplerenone showed clin. relevant redn. in mortality and hospitalization resp. compared with other drug treatments. Further trials with MRAs are warranted to confirm treatment effects in HFpEF.
